docs.lead_paragraph: ''Public Housing'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 4, 1997. The film opens today at the Walter Reade Theater, at Lincoln Center, 165 West 65th Street. ''Public Housing,'' the latest landmark documentary from Frederick Wiseman, sustains Mr. Wiseman's clear-eyed objectivity, a simple but uncanny means of immersing an audience in the world that the camera studies. But in his anatomy of the Ida B. Wells housing project on Chicago's South Side, Mr. Wiseman allows himself one faint bit of editorializing. Several times during the course of this monumental 3-hour-and-20-minute community portrait, Mr. Wiseman lets the viewer notice an ice cream truck that cruises this grim neighborhood and listen as it tootles absurdly cheery nursery songs (e.g. ''Pop Goes the Weasel''). For the 5,000 residents of Ida B. Wells, how can this mean anything but a false promise or a cruel joke?

headline.main: As Life Unfolds at a Housing Project

docs.abstract: Excerpts from Janet Maslin review of Frederick Wiseman documentary Public Housing, which was shown at 1997 New York Film Festival and is now opening in Manhattan (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Over a sharply worded dissent by three Justices, the Supreme Court today turned down the first case to reach it involving a ban on a method of late-term abortion. The Court let stand a ruling by a Federal appeals court that an Ohio law unconstitutionally restricted women's access to abortion by defining the prohibited late-term procedure so broadly that it also effectively banned the most common method of performing ordinary abortions during the second trimester of pregnancy. Ohio asked the Justices to overturn the decision issued last November by the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit, in Cincinnati.

headline.main: Supreme Court Roundup; Overturning of Late-Term Abortion Ban Is Let Stand

docs.abstract: Supreme Court lets stand ruling by US appeals court that Ohio law unconstitutionally restricts women's access to abortion by defining prohibited late-term procedure so broadly that it also effectively bans most common method of performing ordinary abortions during second trimester of pregnancy; Justice Clarence Thomas, joined by Justice Antonin Scalia and Chief Justice William H Rehnquist, writes dissenting opinion; Court turns down challenge to term limits for members of California Legislature that were adopted by state's voters in 1990 referendum; Justices agree to decide whether Screen Actors Guild may enforce collective bargaining agreement that requires union membership as condition of employment (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The story is an old one. A young, unmarried woman becomes pregnant and goes away until the baby is born. Her options, however, are modern: She can have an abortion. She can keep the child and rear it alone. She can keep the child and rear it with her friend and former teacher, Kate, a lesbian, even though Caroline, the mother-to-be, isn't gay. Or she can give the child up for adoption, which is her stated plan. In this case, Caroline (Francie Swift) goes home to the Isle of Wight, where she was born. ''Whale Music,'' written by Anthony Minghella in 1981 and having its New York premiere at Theater Off Park, follows Caroline as she spends her pregnancy surrounded by a motley crew of women friends with strong opinions. Mr. Minghella is now famous for having directed and written the screenplay for ''The English Patient.'' The play offers little of his lyrical language but a good sampling of his wit.

headline.main: A Motley Crew of Women Share a Friend's Pregnancy

docs.abstract: Anita Gates reviews Whale Music, play by Anthony Minghella at Theater Off Park; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: As a mother preparing for her second home birth with Miriam Schwarzchild, I believe a few critical points about home birthing were omitted from your article ''An At-Home Delivery Service, Literally'' (Feb. 22). Home-birthing women and midwives see childbirth not as a medical procedure but a very natural event that is best allowed to evolve at its own pace, in the case of low-risk pregnancies.

headline.main: Profile of a Midwife Omitted Joys of Home Birth

docs.abstract: Heidi Raker Goldstein letter on plans for her second home birth, with help of midwife Miriam Schwarzchild

docs.lead_paragraph: THERE are two commonly held beliefs about today's New York. No. 1: Things are good. No. 2: Everyone agrees about No. 1. The prevailing wisdom holds that the city is basking in a glorious period of renewal, evidenced and enhanced by a robust economy, a revitalized cultural scene and surging self-confidence.

headline.main: New York's Riding High. But How Much Is Hot Air?

docs.abstract: Upbeat news that New York City is basking in a glorious period of economic and social renewal is seen by some resident skeptics as largely a creation of high-powered civic boosters who have a major stake in how the city is percieved; and, the critics say, the city's refurbished image has little to do with the lives of most New Yorkers; sampling of comments suggesting a reality check is due; drawings; photo (L)
